greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of orthogonal 3 X 3 matrices over the ring Z/nZ.
comment: Number of matrices M = [a,b,c; d,e,f; g,h,i] with 0 <= a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, i < n such that M*transpose(M) == [1,0,0; 0,1,0; 0,0,1] (mod n).
For n > 1, a(n) is divisible by 6*A060594(n)^3. - _Robert Israel_, Dec 16 2015
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..124
formula: For p an odd prime, a(p) = 2*p*(p^2-1). - _Tom Edgar_, Nov 04 2015
For odd primes p, a(p^k) = a(p)*p^(3k-3) for k>=1. (End)
maple: for r in R do if not assigned(V[r]) then
for c in S do V[c*r mod n] := 0 od
for i from 1 to nR do
for j from 1 to nRp do
count:= count + 6*(1+nS)^3*nops(select(k -> R[Rp[k]][1]*r1[1] + R[Rp[k]][2]*r1[2]+R[Rp[k]][3]*r1[3] mod n = 0, [$j+1..nRp]));
program: if x*Transpose(x) eq k*M!1 and Transpose(x)*x eq k*M!1 then

(PARI) my(t=Mod(matid(3), n)); sum(a=1, n, sum(b=1, n, sum(c=1, n, sum(d=1, n, sum(e=1, n, sum(f=1, n, sum(g=1, n, sum(h=1, n, sum(i=1, n, my(M=[a, b, c; d, e, f; g, h, i]); M*M~==t))))))))) \\ _Charles R Greathouse_ IV, Nov 10 2015
results.author: _Charles Repizo_, Nov 03 2015
